summary: This document is a technical guide from Sprint Corporate Security explaining how to interpret CDMA Call Detail Reports (CDRs). It provides definitions for columns, explanations of call types, star codes, network element identifiers (NEIDs), and instructions for receiving records in electronic formats. It appears to be a reference document provided in response to a legal request for phone records.
locations: Sprint Corporate Security Mailstop KSOPHM0206 6480 Sprint Parkway Overland Park, KS 66251
keyFacts: The document is a detailed guide from Sprint explaining the structure and interpretation of their CDMA Call Detail Reports (CDRs) for call and text message records.
It explains technical details such as calling/called numbers, dialed digits, call types (Voice, Text Detail, WiFi, VoVoice, Airave), and the significance of network element IDs (NEIDs).
The guide notes a known issue where time stamps for calls between February 4, 2018, and February 28, 2018, may be in GMT instead of local switch time due to a storage upgrade.
It includes a comprehensive list of star codes (e.g., *67 for Caller ID block, *72 for call forwarding) and common short codes that may appear in dialed digits.

The document provides instructions for accessing records provided in electronic formats like RTF, XLS/CSV, and TIF files, often delivered on CD, and includes a full NEID list mapping codes to switch locations and vendors.
